awd_titl_txt: Identifying Genomic Signatures of Evolutionary and Cultural Change in Native Americans
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how Native American genetic diversity changed over time and across space in response to sociocultural and demographic shifts over the last 1000 years. During this period, Native American populations in the continental US were affected by expanding trade networks, a growing reliance on agriculture, increasingly permanent settlements, and population growth. After AD 1492, European contact led to significant cultural changes as well as disease epidemics, demographic collapse, population restructuring, and genetic exchange with new tribes and non-native peoples. These developments are well documented, but it is not known how they influenced the genetic makeup of Native American populations. By characterizing genetic diversity, this project will help elucidate the genetic structure and evolutionary history of Native North Americans, improve our understanding of how sociocultural, demographic, and evolutionary change influences the human genome, and fill a critical need for genome-wide data from the indigenous inhabitants of the continental US, who have been underrepresented in scientific research and public genetic databases.  The project provides research experience and training for undergraduates, graduate students, a postdoctoral researcher, and a K-12 public school science teacher.  Educational modules are also being developed for high school and college science courses and for the Summer Internship for Native Americans in Genomics (SING).  This project therefore advances scientific knowledge, expands the participation of underrepresented groups in science, improves science education, and increases public engagement with science.

Specifically, this project is evaluating temporal and spatial patterns of genetic diversity in the Midwestern US using existing datasets from the region and new genetic data being collected from three burial populations in the Ohio River Basin.  The three major goals are: (1) characterize genomic diversity across time and space in the Ohio River Basin, (2) reconstruct the maternal population history of the Midwestern US using spatially and temporally diverse samples from the Ohio River Basin and the Illinois River Valley, and (3) evaluate whether sociocultural and evolutionary changes between 1000 and 1700 AD altered the genomic structure of an ancient population in the Ohio River Basin. To achieve these goals, genomic data will be collected using newly developed target capture and next-generation sequencing technologies. An extensive set of genomic markers (genome-wide SNPs, mitochondrial DNA sequences, and 23 Y chromosome STRs) will be analyzed, which will make it possible to test hypotheses about how post-1000 AD migration, genetic drift, and selection altered the genetic structure of Native Americans. Mitochondrial data from seven other eastern North American sites will be analyzed to develop models of regional interaction.

por.por_cntn:
Native American genetic diversity has changed over time in North America in response to sociocultural and demographic shifts. The goals of this project were to (a) better understand the changes that have occurred over the last millenium, (b) help elucidate the genetic structure and evolutionary history of Native North Americans, (c) improve our understanding of how sociocultural, demographic, and evolutionary change influences the human genome, and (d) help fill a need for more genome-wide data from Indigenous communities in the continental US, who remain underrepresented in scientific and public genetic databases. 

This project focused primarily on individuals who lived on St. Catherines Island in Georgia in the centuries just before and just after European contact, and who were buried at the Fallen Tree and Santa Catalina de Guale mission cemeteries on the island. With support from local Indigenous representatives and the Georgia Council of American Indian Concerns, members of the Franciscan Order, and the Bishop of Savannah (all representing stakeholder communities), we extracted DNA from the remains of 34 individuals from the Fallen Tree site and 84 individuals from the Santa Catalina de Guale cemetery. Both the maternally-inherited mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and biparentally-inherited autosomal DNA were targeted for sequencing in order to shed light on matrilineal and biparental patterns of relatedness, ancestry, and genetic diversity. Preliminary analyses of the mtDNA and genome-wide data from each burial population were then completed to (1) evaluate relatedness among the individuals buried at these sites, (2) characterize genomic diversity patterns in these communities, and (3) begin to assess how and why genomic diversity shifted over time. We drew on archaeological and ethnohistoric evidence from St. Catherines Island and the broader Southeast to help contextualize and interpret the genomic data.

 While this project was underway, expanded consultations and community engagement identified an Indigenous community with concerns about archaeological and bioarchaeological research on St. Catherines Island. Out of respect for those concerns, we stopped data collection and analysis involving these individuals, and returned all ancestral remains to the St. Catherines Island bioarchaeological collection. Conversations with Indigenous representatives are ongoing, and further analysis of the genomic data will only occur if there is collective Indigenous support for such research.

Over the course of this project, multiple undergraduates, postgraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers benefited from research training and professional development opportunities. Preliminary findings from the project were shared at scientific meetings, and information about the project, what can be learned from genetic analysis, how we obtain ancient DNA from ancestral remains using minimally invasive methodologies, and preliminary findings were discussed with various stakeholder communities, enhancing understandings of this research project and anthropological genetics more broadly. Ongoing efforts to build stronger collaborative partnerships with Indigenous community members in the Southeast will also help facilitate more ethical and engaged anthropological genetic research in the future.
